Let's try heaven. This is the supposed afterlife where everyone gets what they want for eternity.But what if you want your wife for eternity, you die, she re-marries and wants to spend eternity with hubby number two? What if she loves your mother-in-law and you hate the old bat? What if the person you want to spend eternity with did something wrong and ended up in Hell?The heaven concept doesn't work. I know different people see it differently (the most boring I have seen yet is one where we eternally bask in God's love), but I have yet to find one without paradox.  So, now we have ruled out heaven, let's look at the concept of Hell. Now, I like the idea of murderers and rapists going through eternal torture. But how do you really judge this. Paedophilia is pretty evil. But it is also a mental disorder, very often due to the perpetrator having been through similar experiences themselves. In fact the only other ways one becomes seemingly of 'non-normal' sexual behaviour is either through long deprivation from the opposite sex (eg prison or long navy tours), or through enforced sexual abstinence due to pathetic religious ruling (priesthood). So I would not actually condemn a paedophile to eternal torture if their condition was psychological. You might think differently. You might think have different views on murder. Is accidental murder through something like drink driving worthy of eternal torture just as much as deliberately flying a plane into a building? So this is where Hell falls down. One size does not fit all. In my novel, Psychic Warrior, I imagine an afterlife where our own 'souls' first punish us for all the bad we have done in mortal life and then reward us for the good, so it becomes a self-inflicted Hell followed by self-rewarding heaven. It has advantages. Innocent children can bypass Hell and go straight to reward, without the need of baptism or other religious ceremony. It also has drawn backs. A religious zealot who has harmed no one might inflict immense torture upon himself for a moment of weakness, whereas Hitler might only give himself a 'short' Hell period because he believed what he was doing wasn't evil. There's more to it than that, but although it's fiction, it's a lot more thought out than the current concept and it didn't take long to do. So I have to answer a resounding no to whether or not there is a heaven and hell. I have seen no evidence to support an afterlife, yet a tiny bit of me wants my version (mainly because I know the rest of the story) and that is why religion thrives. Before I was atheist, I subscribed to an afterlife. Without any evidence. Losing faith in a god is easy. Losing the hope of something after our short time on this planet is a lot harder. That's why religion uses hope as its ultimate con to keep us coming to the sermons and leaving our cash on the collection plates.

Yes, heaven and hell really exist. Both are distinct locations in this universe, but even on this planet it is an observable fact that some people live in a heavenly situation and some people live under hellish circumstances. So it could be said that both heaven and hell are on this planet. But apart from that there are heavenly planets within this universe and there are hellish planets as well. Let med tell you about what happens at the point of death, according to the Bhagavat-purana. If you have been very good and pious, you will upon leaving the body be led to the planets of the demigods - the heavenly planets, called Svarga. There you will enjoy for millions of years before again you will be born on earth as a human. On the heavenly planets you enjoy basically as you do on earth - sex, drugs and rockn,roll - but it takes place on a subtle plane, the astral plane as some call it. You are in a subtle body - a psychic, finer physical body that doesn't exude excretions. IOW, you don't perspire, fart or stink. In heaven there are heavenly dancing girls and the soma-drink - an intoxication that makes you feel good and prolongs life. The music is delivered by the gandharvas - some sort of angles who are the musicians of the heavenly planets. On the heavenly planets there is no disease or old age, but eventually you die and fall back to a human body on earth. Now, at the point of death, if you have been very cruel and evil not caring or empathizing with other living entities, you will be picked up by the Yamadutas, the messengers of Yamaraja - the god of Death - and taken to the hellish planets, where you will be tortured and undergo purgatory for what feels like eternity. Like on the heavenly planets, it happens on a subtle, astral plane, so a moment can feel like a long, long time - like in a dream. After having ended your prescribed suffering, you will again be born on earth, but not necessarily from a human womb. You can be born in any of the 8.400.000 species of life. If you have just been an ordinary, somewhat decent human, neither too good nor too evil, like people are most, at the point of death you will fall into a deep sleep and stay like that for 7 months after which you'll wake up and find yourself tied up in a womb. The situation for the fetus is full of pain and distress. You are in full consciousness but you are totally bound up and gagged, it's like being bound up very tightly in a sack. If you are lucky, you will remember everything you did to land you in this particular womb, why you will be born to certain parents. Then after 2 months of such hell you are squeezed out of a hole much too little for you, and born in shock into total forgetfulness. The foster state is described in the Bhagavat Purana in great detail. If, however, you have practiced spiritual life and think of Krishna at the time of death, you will return to the spiritual world in your original constitution of eternity, knowledge and bliss. Or you will be born in some universe on some planet where Krishna has descended to reveal His pastimes. When that period has ended, you will return with Krishna to Goloka either as one of His friends, His girl-friends or as His elder in a parental mood. The choice is yours. Where ever you go after death will be according to how you formed your mental body. The mental or the psychic body is formed after the activities of your gross, physical body and the mentality you are cultivating. Krishna says: And whoever, at the end of his life, quits his body remembering Me alone at once attains My nature. Of this there is no doubt. (Bg. 8.5) Whatever state of being one remembers when he quits his body, O son of Kunti, that state he will attain without fail. (Bg 8.6)

I grew up as a Christian believing in a literal heaven and hell, until I looked into it further. I don't know if Jesus was the son of God, no one does. Anyone who says that they know that to be true beyond a shadow of a doubt are kidding themselves. To truly believe anything, you must doubt it. If you refuse to doubt, you don't have faith that your beliefs can overcome said doubts. And if the doubts prove to be relevant, one simply learns. It's a win/win, really. Anywho, I do have a great respect for the Bible and Jesus, as I believe both contain valuable information that contributes to a spiritual mindset. The reason I no longer believe in the evangelical hell is as follows: The Jewish people had no "hell. " They had "Sheol. " Ancient Jews were a lot more comfortable with uncertainty than Western Christians are. Sheol was simply the state of being dead. They had something of a mythology dedicated to it down the road, but if you go back far enough, you see that Sheol had a bit of mystery behind it. Even so, Sheol in the later days was more like a purgatory than hell. One of the first mentions of hell (eternal flames hell) is in the New Testament The Jewish people at this time had pretty much been absorbed by the Romans. The Romans had a tendency to steal aspects of culture that they liked, including a lot of Greek mythology. This is why when the disciples spoke of this eternal punishment, they used the word "Tartarus” or “Hades.” They'd begun to abandon their roots. Jesus, on the other hand, clearly had a different idea about hell. He used the word Gahenna. Gahenna was commonly known to be a place where one burns their garbage in those times. It was in the center of the city, and it was on fire at all times. It wasn't, however, a place of torture. In fact, the gates never closed. Everyone had open access to it at all times. This fact combined with Jesus' constant teachings of love and selflessness lead both I and many theologians to believe that Jesus referred to hell on Earth. Child Abuse, spousal abuse, addiction, rape. Any "sin" (translated to mean separation from God (love, life) you choose what that is for you) is an example of hell on Earth, more or less. Just like Gahenna, all are welcome to either enter or leave. Why would anyone stay in hell some ask. Any person with any intelligence would just leave. But if you believe in an integral worldview (one in which spirituality and physicality are not only parallel but intertwined), most Christians would claim to, you have to accept that just as a rapist or abusive parent choose to experience hell on earth every day, they'd do the same thing in the "afterlife” Another theory, that can be used in conjunction with the last, is the idea that Gahenna is a place much like Sheol, a purgatory. People entered Gahenna to burn their trash (or sin) not their bodies. It is amusing to think that most evangelicals would cringe at the thought of paganism, yet one of their greatest beliefs and subjects of fear comes directly from Greek mythology. This was the commonly accepted belief before the protestant reformation, that's where the modern Westernized church was born. The concept of eternal hell goes nicely with Greek Gods of petty jealousy and war, not so much with the love and selflessness taught by Christ. Some make an argument for an Old Testament Christian God of wrath, but if you ask me, that's just an example of primitive humans interpreting spiritual experiences in a very primitive way. Just look at the things they did. They committed genocide. Multiple times. Jesus says "turn the other cheek.” it doesnt add up at all. God may have given us the Bible, but man gave us the English translation. God did however give us brains, so I can't imagine that he doesn't expect us to analyze a little bit. Thats one possibility. The other: Nah, there's no such thing as hell ;)

The universe very much appears to work on some kind of binary system, although it might not strictly be 1s and 0s per se, it could be some other things… Proponents of the simulation hypothesis claim that our world may in fact be a digital program that was created by beings infinitely more technologically advanced than ourselves. I don't necessarily believe this to be true. I think the material universe is the work of a being that far exceeds our comprehension, that exceeds any concept of time or space, an omnipotent and omniscient intelligence, not merely a creature. But the fact that our world mirrors a simulation shows that it isn't in the least absurd to believe in God. You decide.The Case for the SoulBut does the biblical heaven, and the biblical hell actually exist? Let's first start with what the King James Bible refers to as “Hell”, which is translated from a variety of different words in the original Hebrew and Greek. One such word is Γέεννα, i.e. "gehenna", which is not a Greek word, but a transliteration of the Hebrew name (גֵּיהִנּוֹם‎, gēhinnôm), which refers to the perpetually burning trash dump in a small valley below the walls of Jerusalem. As the sack is tossed and caught between the two boats, there are waves, or ripples, that reach out and affect all four boats in the water. On the quantum level, subatomic particles work in a similar fashion. There are about four total that we can see interact with other particles, and they all affect the others in particular ways, even when not interacting with them. Anything in our physical world is noticeably affected by other things through QFT. That means, when objects like quarks appear randomly, and then disappear after a fraction of a second, it is detected on the quantum level by the particles they affect. So, if any supernatural element, say an ever-present deity, heaven, hell, spirits, demons, etc., came into or out of our physical realm, it would be detectable. NOW ABOUT HELL 2. There is no Hell. What Really Is Hell? WHATEVER image the word “hell” brings to your mind, hell is generally thought of as a place of punishment for sin. Concerning sin and its effect, the Bible says: “Through one man sin entered into the world and death through sin, and thus death spread to all men because they had all sinned.” (Romans 5:12) The Scriptures also state: “The wages sin pays is death.” (Romans 6:23) Since the punishment for sin is death, the fundamental question in determining the true nature of hell is: What happens to us when we die? Does life of some kind, in some form, continue after death? What is hell, and what kind of people go there? Is there any hope for those in hell? The Bible gives truthful and satisfying answers to these questions. Life After Death? Does something inside us, like a soul or a spirit, survive the death of the body? Consider how the first man, Adam, came to have life. The Bible states: “Jehovah God proceeded to form the man out of dust from the ground and to blow into his nostrils the breath of life.” (Genesis 2:7) Though breathing sustained his life, putting “the breath of life” into his nostrils involved much more than simply blowing air into his lungs. (Genesis 6:17; 7:22) The Bible refers to this animating force as “spirit.” (James 2:26) That spirit can be compared to the electric current that activates a machine or an appliance and enables it to perform its function. Just as the current never takes on the features of the equipment it activates, the life-force does not take on any of the characteristics of the creatures it animates. It has no personality and no thinking ability. The ancient Greek philosophers Socrates and Plato held that a soul inside a person survives death and never dies. What does the Bible teach about the soul? Adam “came to be a living soul,” says Genesis 2:7. He did not receive a soul; he was a soul —a whole person. The Scriptures speak of a soul’s doing work, craving food, being kidnapped, experiencing sleeplessness, and so forth. (Leviticus 23:30;Deuteronomy 12:20; 24:7; Psalm 119:28) Yes, man himself is a soul. When a person dies, that soul dies. —Ezekiel 18:4. What, then, is the condition of the dead? When pronouncing sentence upon Adam, Jehovah stated: “Dust you are and to dust you will return.” (Genesis 3:19) Where was Adam before God formed him from the dust of the ground and gave him life? Why, he simply did not exist! When he died, Adam returned to that state of complete absence of life. In the grave, where you are going, there is neither working nor planning nor knowledge nor wisdom.” (New International Version) Scripturally, death is a state of nonexistence. The dead have no awareness, no feelings, no thoughts. Unending Torment or Common Grave? Since the dead have no conscious existence, hell cannot be a fiery place of torment where the wicked suffer after death. What, then, is hell? Examining what happened to Jesus after he died helps to answer that question. The Bible writer Luke recounts: “Neither was [Jesus] forsaken in Hades [hell, King James Version] nor did his flesh see corruption.”*(Acts 2:31) Where was the hell to which even Jesus went? The apostle Paul wrote: “I handed on to you . . . that Christ died for our sins according to the Scriptures; and that he was buried, yes, that he has been raised up the third day according to the Scriptures.” (1 Corinthians 15:3, 4) So Jesus was in hell, the grave, but he was not abandoned there, for he was raised up, or resurrected. Consider also the case of the righteous man Job, who suffered much. Wishing to escape his plight, he pleaded: “Who will grant me this, that thou mayest protect me in hell [Sheol], and hide me till thy wrath pass?”*(Job 14:13, Douay Version) How unreasonable to think that Job desired to go to a fiery-hot place for protection! To Job, “hell” was simply the grave, where his suffering would end. The Bible hell, then, is the common grave of mankind where good people as well as bad ones go. NOW ABOUT HEAVEN 3. One day, A disciple requested his master, “Pray, please grant me a vision of heaven. It’s been so long now that I’ve been serving you.” “My child,” the master said, “go and sit in the next room. Close your eyes and sit still. You’ll see heaven.” “Really? Just like that.” “Go.” The disciple went into the next room and meditated. Surely enough, he had a vision but it was far from what he expected. All he saw was a vast ground and nothing else. There weren’t any beautiful palaces or rivers of honey. Just as there were no oceans of milk or bricks of ruby. The roofs were not diamond studded. Heck, there was nothing other than endless barren land. As disappointed as intrigued, he went back to his master. “O, my murshid,” he pleaded hiding his disappointment. “Now that I’ve seen heaven, I should certainly like to see hell.” “Hmm…” The master stroked his white flowing beard. “Very well then, go and sit in meditation again. You’ll have a vision of hell.” The disciple did as instructed and once again, he saw nothing but the same vacant land. There were no fire-spitting snakes, no devil or ferocious animals, no one flaying anyone, no pots of boiling oil. Wherever he looked, there was just empty land from where he stood to all the way to the horizon, in all directions. “What the hell,” he thought. “This certainly couldn’t be it.” “Master,” he spoke with conviction. “This was anything but a vision. I saw no heaven or hell.” “You mean you were expecting glorious structures, magnificent scenery and unearthly beauty in heaven?” “Yes.” “Or, snakes, fire, devil or untold tortures in hell?” “Exactly.” “My son,” the master said. “There is nothing there. You will have to take everything from here. This is the place to gather everything, either the delights of heaven or the fires of hell.” Heaven and hell are two aspects of our attitude towards life. These are two warehouses of our emotions and karma. How stuffy it gets here, whether it’s fragrant or foul, it all depends on what we have stored in these warehouses. When we are content and grateful, we are in heaven. When we are angry, perturbed, or jealous we are in hell. Both are phases, stages and cyclical states of our mind. Heaven is indeed the vision of fulfilled desire, and hell the shadow of a soul on fire. In this infinite creation of unimaginable proportions, our acquisitions and attainments have little significance. Our world is tinier than the tiniest speck of dust in the world. Ultimately, to the world at large, what matters is not how fat your bank balance is but how big your heart is. Every selfless act, every gesture of gratitude, every soft word, every kind thought, they make up who we are. They create our world. Heaven or hell, it’s not just within us, it is us.
